content.description:
“Which is the German’s fatherland?

Is’t Prussia’s or Swabia’s land?

Is’t where the Rhine’s rich vintage streams?

Or where the Northern sea-gull screams?—

Ah, no, no, no!

His fatherland’s not bounded so!

Which is the German’s fatherland?

Come, tell me now the famous land.

Doubtless, it is the Austrian state,

In honors and in triumphs great.—

Ah, no, no, no!

His fatherland’s not bounded so!

Which is the German’s fatherland?

So tell me now at last the land!—

As far’s the German’s accent rings

And hymns to God in heaven sings,—

That is the land,—

There, brother, is thy fatherland!

There is the German’s fatherland,

Where oaths attest the grasped hand,—

Where truth beams from the sparkling eyes,

And in the heart love warmly lies;—

That is the land,—

There, brother, is thy fatherland!

That is the German’s fatherland,

Where wrath pursues the foreign band,—

Where every Frank [French person] is held a foe,

And Germans all as brothers glow;—

That is the Land,—

All Germany’s thy fatherland!”

Ernst Arndt, German poet, “The German Fatherland,” 1813
content.question: The widespread acceptance of the concept of Germany’s boundaries reflected in the poem would lead most directly to which of the following?

choices.label: The partition of Poland between Austria, Prussia, and Russia
Conflict between Bismarck’s Prussia and neighboring powers
The creation of the Dual Monarchy
French resentment at the terms of the peace settlement at the Congress of Vienna

content.answer: Conflict between Bismarck’s Prussia and neighboring powers

skill.text: Skill 5.B: Explain how a historical development or process relates to another historical development or process.
